name: Taxing RP with Enhanced Login Protocol
description:
Unsure about House of Knives, these maybe should be False Lead. I want to do the 3322222211 split though, and the other 1-pointers look worse besides perhaps Gila Hands Arcology. I could also switch Nisei MK II for Fetal AI to make the agendas harder to steal; if so, I would probably cut the Hive since part of their value is helping get a Nisei MK II scored.

The 1-of Swordsman is there to mise Knight and Atman, but it's possible it should just be a third Himitsu-Bako. It is tempting to make everything besides agendas 3-ofs.

name: Duggar's Sympathy - Refined
NoiseShop
By Hook or by crook v0.1X
description:
Moving away from the Street Chess style, this is based on a deck design that one of the local guys played to fairly good effect, but stripping out some extraneous complexity (e.g. Cloak & Dagger).

Combining Grappling Hook and e3 Feedback Implants makes breaking any multi-subroutine ice appallingly cheap, and Exile gains cards for each cycle of the Hook back into play, for a potent break/draw engine. The killer for the Hook is single subroutine ice, and Overmind excels at dealing with such defences. When the Hook isn't available, e3 combined with Overmind means saving power counters to break through.

"By crook" refers to the use of Sneakdoor Beta to skip around HQ ice and spread the Corp defences thin. Femme Fatale is the other "crook" technology that cares little about ice strength.

The specialised Shaper breakers - Deus X and Sharpshooter provide utility to pull in extra trash to break capability that isn't reliant upon the combo pieces and Inti is there for the nigh-ubiquitous Wraparound, as well as NEXT Silver, Paper Wall and early Ice Wall. In a pinch it can also deal with Himitsu-Bako when there's nothing else available.

Leprechaun opens up the possibility of hosting cards that enable the attack vector without drawing MU away from the Overmind (crucial only at install time). Using Scavenge allows you to recharge either Overmind or Imp counters, with Exile getting a bonus draw for resetting these cards. Scavenge also allows cheating in Femme Fatale off a Test Run.

Modifications: v0.1X Swapped out 2x Professional Contacts for 2x Magnum Opus Dropped 1x Test Run, 1x Scavenge for 2x Self-modifying Code Dropped 1x Sharpshooter for third Omni-Drive.

name: Nasir, ICE Explorer 1.5
Classic Noise Mill
description:
Classic Noise mill inspired by one of SlySquid's initial list with my personal variations based on my playstyle. The early versions have very low econ but surprisingly enough can fend for itself thanks to the Cyberfeeders which I believe is a staple to any Noise deck. The inclusion of Cache made a huge econ bump because it usually provides 5-7 credits thanks to Cyberfeeder, Aesop and Grimoire.

Early game: Mulligan hard for Wyldside. It's what will help the deck in the long run. Keep running with Imps on the board to let them rez those ICE for fear of trashing their much needed cards. A Medium or Nerve Agent in hand will tell you which of the servers you want to keep ramming through and laying those Parasites. Keep checking the archives for agendas and grow those Datasucker tokens. You'll need them during the course of the game.

Mid/Late game: You don't need to keep on running every turn at this stage. What you want to do is keep playing those viruses. With Cyberfeeders, Cache and Aesop's, the virus cards are all cheap to play. Wyldside will provide you a steady stream of viruses in hand and so does Deja Vu and Clone Chips. If you fear getting Scorched since there's no Plascrete in here, which to me is totally unneccessary, run on Archives to let them rez ICE, Parasite it via Clone Chip, kill it using Datasucker tokens and then jack out so you don't get SEA Sourced next turn. One final run with the help of Knights into Archives will secure you the win so I use these sparingly unless I really need to such as a locked R&D with Medium.

Remember, you don't have to get to 7 agenda points if you think that you can just deck them out. This deck is capable of doing that if you don't get agendas in the early game on your archive runs or R&D runs with Medium.

Although some people think that Jackson gives this deck a hard time getting those agendas, on the contrary, it actually isn't. The viruses are so cheap that you can consistently mill 3-4 cards every turn. And if the corp is using Jackson to draw some cards then let him. That will get you closer to your goal.

Djinn, which was a 3rd Grimoire, is a great card and I'm happy to include it. Besides the benefit of hosting 3 non-icebreaker programs, it's ability to fetch for viruses, especially Parasites, is its best use. Don't be afraid to use this every turn even if only for getting a Cache or Gorman. Cache returns the money I spent while Gorman slows down the corp because most of the time they try minimize using clicks by drawing cards or gettings creds.

"But Keyhole does a better job than this and so does Data Leak Reversal."

Keyhole requires me to run on R&D and in turn I have to have my suite of breakers and creds to benefit from it's effect. I do get to choose a card that is trashed but I'd rather just spend a cred to trash that card using my virus. And if that card was Cache, I just earned 2-4 creds rather than spending anything at all.

Data Leak Reversal needs to have a lot of cards to synergize with it effectively and at most, it doesn't stay in play that long. It's much more simpler spending a cred or two for playing a virus card to mill a card.

Some considerations:

What I'd make to include in the list is an Eden Shard. It's a counter against Jackson but it seems a bit overkill to just include a card specifically against it.

I'd also like another Aesop in there probably in place of one Clone Chip. Sometimes I just want to get rid of programs because I have lots of them on the board all the time. A 3rd Aesop gives me a better chance of getting one early.

The deck used to have a piece of The Source and Chakana each against fast advance. I removed them entirely and settled for a higher virus count. But if I were to put them back in, I'd remove a Clone Chip and the two Gorman Drips.

In closing, this deck is a very fun to play and most of the time slows the corp because the loss of their essential cards. They'd start securing Archives or start digging for Jacksons. If that's the case then it only shows that I control the pace of the game. And we all know that doesn't bode well for the corp.

name: White Lotus Noise
description: Noise with econ and a "proper" breaker suite. Make bank, run recklessly, try not to get scorched. Inspired by the several Noise builds that have been going round lately.

name: GRNDL - 2 steps forward
description: Rush deck inspired by the GRNDL's wisps thread on bgg. Troubleshooter is no good vs D4V1D, so he gets dropped for other things. Game plan is to score out your 3ptrs fast. Shaper is the hardest matchup, so you try and put them in a situation where they either run and get killed, or run and lose a breaker - to open up a scoring window.

name: Enhanced Victory protocol
Haas Bioroid - stopping power
HB Low Ice No Ice
description: I only chose 2 point agendas to flesh out the agenda cardpool (adding NAPD Contract is a no brainer) and added domestic sleepers to add even more possibilities. The number of Asset and Agenda is almost equal which is fun for obvious reasons. I have enough economy cards to keep it going and my ice are fairly cheap. You aren't going to be rich but you are gonna be able to save some creds with you SanSans. You can play this deck in many different ways. Enjoy.

name: First design on a jinteki
description: First random design, not built, just started playing netrunner. Any ideas? I think i need more ice but not sure what to cut

name: Tennin Stop!
The Redish Coats
description: basically nordrunners red coats, added a couple taurus and couple punitive for fun

name: The Red Singularity
description: With the rise of Near-Earth Hub, Singularity may be something. While it is expensive, with some Prepaid, it may be just the thing you need to thrash those damn SanSan or any server filled with upgrades. It works great too against traps and Ash (sucks against Caprice) The idea here is to make expensive to rez ice with Rook and Reina and thrash anything you can. Keyhole focus should be Jackson > Anything (except if thrashing will mean victory, of course). There is a fine line to choose between Agendas and Biotics or SanSans. Grab The Source as fast as you can and thrash it with Aesop when you are ready to score. This is a first step with no tests and I'm looking for feedback.

name: Chaos Theory Medium Cyber Exodus
description:
This is a deck I built with the cards I had available (which is up through Cyber Exodus).

The idea is to use Chaos Theory for speed, building up the rig and then putting loads of pressure onto R&D with Medium (in practice, I've found I tend to have a Test Run on hand to summon up an extra card, so I could use it for Medium). It removes some of the fun surprise from Medium, it makes sure it gets into the rig when it's needed near the end.

I have trouble getting up and running fast enough, but I think it's mostly because my play style isn't focused enough.

I'm very open to recommendations so long as they use cards in the core set or the first 3 datapacks (What Lies Ahead, Trace Amount or Cyber Exodus).

name: Reverse Transaction
description:
Version 1.2. The previous version won a tournament of 12 players in Joensuu, Finland, August 2014. The playerbase was somewhat new and I got a roll of good match ups, but the deck worked rather well nontheless.

The idea is to keep the Runner broke. All the time. Most of the ICE and Upgrades are meant to either tax or use the Identity special. See Ash 2X3ZB9CY and Ichi 2.0 for example. Scoring windows are made with Ash+Red Herrings+RSVP

RSVP is something I enjoy a lot in here. It's mainly a cheap Code Gate that nullifies Yog.0. You could possibly play one or two Project Junebug which could get a kill through RSVP with an AstroScript Pilot Program counter, but I can't bluff that well. Shinobi is there to make the kill, and it's more likely to do it than a Junebug.

Tax them for playing Account Siphon with Closed Accounts, and against non-Siphon decks just spam them with Tags with the likes of Restructured Datapool. Interns has so much utility it's not even funny. Wait... it is, actually. Use it for Ash or Red Herrings, or even SanSan City Grid.

Really fun to play with, and a Runner without money can't really do much good. Criminals don't like this, and even Anarchs don't pose that much of a threat these days with so much Siphon coming from that direction. Can't say how this would handle Shaper.

Much of the money comes in with plain-ol' Clicks. Don't worry about it - just take it. Cover R&D with most of the ICE. HQ isn't that much of a problem generally. R&D lock might ruin your day.

You could switch an Ichi 2.0 with another Shinobi if you wanted. Both are grand.

name: First run on nbn, suggestions welcome
description: Not built , just designing

name: Nisei scorch
description:
A deck for people interested in playing Nisei Division, but don't know where to begin.

Based on a highly tested PE build I was working on, but abandoned. This deck focuses on a scorched or scorched EMP flatline, while taxing the piss out of the runner with cheap ice. Basically you should be sticking things into the remote every turn after solidifying it. Play as never advance, but use TFP when you think you can score, otherwise, they're just a PITA to steal. I would consider making some cuts to put Braintrust in instead of TFP just to continue with Never Advance.

name: Nasir vs. Goliath
description:
Of all the ways I've tried to splash a 4 influence card in Nasir, I'm convinced this has to be the best (sorry Morning Star and Siphon, A for effort). I've dropped 2 Acct. Siphons from my big rig Nasir build, freeing up a whopping 8 inf. so D4v1d + E3 is in and that freed up room for a one-off Parasite. I've also put in an Aesop's so that you can sell off Cache and D4v1d before clone-chipping them back out (Scavenging them will also work, but it won't provide the 3 credits from ol' Aesop).

Two questions about consistency though. With only one each of e3 and Aesop's, I'm worried about not seeing them in time to be useful. In order to free up the 2 inf. for e3, I'd drop Parasite. It's a useful program to have up your sleeve, but I've been playing without it to pretty good effect. And I'd also have to free up a second slot for Aesop's or just play with 46 cards. This is the aspect of deckbuilding I always struggle with, so any insight would be hugely appreciated!

name: Mutating Bioroids 2.0
description:
Updated my "Quandry Gets Multiple Subroutines!" deck. Unfortunately, I had to abandon poor quandary due to instant and normal parasite recursion, she never lives long enough to mutate against those builds.

I've updated to a more diverse win-condition set with BL and 3/2s as I started to get better at having cash on hand.

Also I added Tyr's hand due to so much of my ice getting clicked. Now with Tyr's hand, you can let a runner go through your wotan, and deny him on the last or clicks subroutine for luls.

Reducing the ice count due to how much I was throwing away, when levy university is available, you just need less ice, so this lead to taking out ABT and replacing with vitruvious to help recur cards like mutate, BL and economy. I removed viktor 2 due to the lower money in the deck, I did not find that I needed a semi porous early game ice, vs the times I would mutate it out disappointingly.

Now the deck sings with NeXT bronze surviving 1 turn to mutate, filter the whole deck of small ice in 1 turn with levy (most times). BL to wrap up the game when you early score behind 2 fatties (usually 5 points or so).

It's kind of funny, people see me use levy to go get Bronze and they presume its some NeXT/Grail ice based deck, which can be mildly exploited. I also love to see a runner tutor up a breaker, only to have me mutate the heimdall 2.0 into an ichi 2.0 over another heimdall.

Often times a play would be to mutate a BER or OAI'ed ice to make it permanent, and not derez/trashable, and then reuse the BER/OAI with AM to rez big ice on your scoring remote. This deck is amazingly flexible, fun, and can actually win now! Leave your thoughts!

name: The MedTech Hustle
description: My take on a fast advance MedTech. Everyone and their mothers runs just 6 agendas in MedTech, I'm running 7 to see them more consistently. The deck has strong econ and some pretty taxing ICE that's also relatively cheap to rez (this IS fast advance, after all). Should the runner get net damage, Tori Hanzo is there to punish them further.

name: Cacheconomy - Akamatsu Edition
Burgundy Blazers (v0.4)
description:
I went 6-1 with this list at the Thursday flight of US Nationals at GenCon, missing the top 32 cut by one win (2-5 on the Runner side). I beat two Silhouettes, a Noise, a Prepaid Kate, a Whizzard, and a Gabe. My one loss was to a Vamp Ken where I was agenda flooded and Jacksonless for much of the game - problematic in any matchup, and particularly when Siphon/Vamp are involved.

I'll be testing Enhanced Login Protocol over Ash an adding a Caprice to compensate.

name: LepreKatman (v0.2)
description:
I went a whopping 2-5 with this deck at the Thursday flight of US Nationals, and missed the cut by one win. There was definitely a lot of pilot error as I didn't have enough testing time, but I also think the deck takes just a bit too long to get set up against NEH. They can often get one agenda scored before you have Opus/Leprechaun, SMC, and cash - even with Imp aggression. On the other hand, a rig of Opus, SMC, Datasucker, 2x Atman has some serious inevitability.

I'll be keeping this around, but it still needs work.

name: Run all the things! - isc
Illusionary garden of Zen - isc
description: Flatline. Lol

name: Eventfull Connections
description: my iain deck that im currently running.

name: Rotations!
Shady Kate
description:
Sort of a "back-to-basics" approach for me. In the past, I always had trouble balancing the consistent econ of Opus with consistent MU shortages. With the release of Leprechaun, it's possible to be much more agile even before you get any extra MU out on the table. The fact that it can host two programs regardless of their MU means SMCs, Opus, and Garrots aren't as tough to manage as before.

I'm fond of "drip" and recurring economy for the runner, so Underworld Contacts and The Toolbox were obvious choices. I don't always put a Toolbox in play, but when it does hit the table, it typically earns its keep.

Replicators are in to help speed things along, especially when it comes to The Personal Touch - which remains a versatile way to tackle various ICE strategies. 2 on a Corroder makes Eli cheap. One or two on Gordian can help against heavy NEXT ICE usage. etc. Of course, Will-o'-the-Wisp means you can't rely too heavily on them anymore.

Sharpshooter and Sacrificial Construct are there to help protect you from potentially devastating Leprechaun destruction. A single Scrubber makes an appearance to help against all of the PE and NEH asset decks that are going around lately.

Typically I mulligan if I don't see a MO or a Luck Find plus either a SMC or a Pro. Contacts. This deck is definitely a "late game" superstar and can fairly effectively push to that end fairly quickly, but it definitely requires a bit of setup and econ is the key to that.

Feedback always welcome and encouraged!

name: Rotations!
Chip and Rezz
description:
This is a Criminal deck my friend Fosforo built and I tuned up a little. The so many events it's to start entring the central servers and boicot the Corp with Account Siphon and the combo Forged Activation Orders with Cortez Chip

It's 46 and not 45 cards because I wanted the 2nd Femme Fatale, very useful in case you want to baypass other ice.

There are only 7 icebreakers (and 3 special orders) since the most common disposal is Crypsis, other icebreaker and the sneakdoor. Occasionaly with the Desperado would be another one.

name: Jinteki passive aggresive
Polytron Corp
description: Polytron Corp is now ripe for the picking, internet. Get all the bad publicity you can and get your executive to leave the playing field. Bonus points if you can get him back to do it again.

name: First design on a jinteki.2
description: First random design, not built, just started playing netrunner. Any ideas? I think i need more ice but not sure what to cut

name: R&D Deep Scan
description: Total newbie deck I've made from my single core and expansions but have not lost yet with. A relentless attack on R&D basically.
